text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with chocolate granola that's right
do not let the name fool you it only
sounds like we're making granola less
healthy in fact we are probably making
it more nutritious since we're gonna be
getting all those well-documented health
benefits of chocolate without having to
add any additional sugar at least if you
use this technique and trust me this is
the technique you're gonna want to use
since it's fast easy and the results are
unbelievably delicious so with that
let's go ahead and get started and first
up we have to make our mud which is what
I've dubbed the chocolate base we're
about to create and that's going to
start with some light brown sugar as
well as the maple syrup formerly known
as great B I believe now they call it
robust which I'm still not comfortable
with but anyway continuing on we'll also
need a little bit of vegetable oil or if
you're into it some melted coconut oil
would also work perfectly here we will
also want to drip in a little bit of
pure real vanilla extract and then it's
very important we season this up with
some salt as well as the technically
optional Cayenne which I could have done
anywhere
but I did it on the salt cuz I thought
it would look cool alright don't forget
we're not just cooking we're also sort
of painting and then last but not least
we'll finish up with our star ingredient
some cocoa and by the way well I'm sure
there's a lot of Coco's that will work
for this I'm using a very beautiful
Dutch process cocoa Rouge which I will
go over in excruciating detail in the
blog post and then once all that's in
there we'll take a whisk and give this a
thorough mixing and believe it or not
that's going to be it for our chocolate
granola base which is I mentioned
earlier we've dubbed the mud for obvious
reasons and then once that very simple
and easy step is done we are ready to
add whatever grains and nuts we're gonna
be using here which for me is simply
going to be some rolled oats as well as
some incredibly cocoa friendly chopped
almonds and while there are like a
hundred other things you could add to
this I'm just using these two because I
really want to keep the flavor profile
simple so as not to have a lot of other
tastes and textures competing with my
chocolate but anyway once our mud has
been grained and nutted we will take our
biggest bestest spatula and we'll mix
this up using the old toss and smear
which you can see me performing here
so we will rotate that bowl around while
we alternate between tossing and
smearing the mixture together and we
will continue doing that until this is
utterly and thoroughly mixed and by
mixed I mean every single particle of
oatmeal and almond should be covered
with that chocolate mud and if it's not
do not stop all right well you can't
over mix this you certainly can under
mix it so take your time and make us
proud and then once that is all
perfectly mixed we'll go ahead and
transfer that onto a Silpat lined baking
sheet and obviously spread it out as
evenly as possible not just so it looks
cool but so that it bakes evenly and of
course I should mention just cuz I'm
keeping mine super simple doesn't mean
you have to I mean you are after all the
j hovah of your chocolate granola so
feel free to add any other granola
appropriate seeds nuts and grains you
see fit but like I said when I'm doing a
chocolate version of this I think just
the oatmeal and almond works the best
but regardless of what you're using once
that's all been successfully spread out
it is ready to transfer into the center
of a 250 degree oven for approximately
60 to 90 minutes or until done
quote-unquote and we will talk about
doneness a little later but what I like
to do after about 30 minutes let's go
ahead and pull it out and we will give
this a toss with a fork
breaking up any large pieces that are
sticking together which reminds me if
you want big pieces that are sticking
together do not do this step which is
completely okay but if you do want a
granola with a finer texture like I do
you probably will want to work this over
as shown and then once that's been
accomplished we'll go ahead and pop that
back in but not before of course tasting
a little pinch which only after a half
hours not going to be done and it's
still going to be pretty soft and chewy
but it was actually starting to get a
little bit crunchy but anyway after this
optional forking will go ahead and put
that back in until we think it's done
and how long that takes total is going
to depend on what you put in your
mixture and also how crisp and crunchy
you want this okay some people like a
soft and chewy and other people like a
very crunchy and crisp so we'll pop that
back in the oven and continue on at 250
checking it as needed until we think
it's gone long enough and one big tip
here for testing that you're not going
to really be able to judge it until it's
cooled off so to check this what I'll do
is transfer a little bit of this onto a
plate
which will cause it to cool quickly at
which point we can touch it and listen
to it and if it sounds like little
pieces of glass hitting to play you're
probably done but of course we'll want
to eat something to double-check and I'm
happy to report mine was perfect which
brings us to one last optional step I
like to let my cool into turned off oven
so once done I'll simply pop mine back
in turn off the heat and let that sit in
there slowly cooling until it's room
temp and I think that helps it dry out
just a little bit more and maybe adds a
little extra crispiness without risking
overcooking so this is what mine look
like a couple hours later completely
cooled and ready to consume and of
course we're gonna want to transfer that
into some kind of airtight container
like one of these glass latch top jars
or if you're not taking pictures just
some Tupperware and that's it our
chocolate granola is officially ready to
enjoy which is absolutely wonderful as
is but while it's totally fine by itself
it's even better in my opinion too
combined with some vanilla yogurt to
create a simple yet beautiful parfait
that we may or may not want to top a
little bit of fresh fruit and by the way
the only difference between this
presented is a breakfast and this
presented is a dessert is what you serve
it in okay if you use one of these fancy
Sunday glasses it's a dessert whereas if
we put the same ingredients in a cereal
bowl it's a breakfast that really is the
only difference and even though it might
seem kind of decadent and naughty it
really is not okay compared to a lot of
granola recipes this one has a
shockingly small amount of sugar in it
and yet our chocolate flavor is very
pronounced very intense and I have to
admit even though I'm sort of a closet
hippy I've never been a huge fan of
granola but this chocolate version I
absolutely love and by the way with
Mother's Day coming up if your mom is a
fan of chocolate which I'm gonna take a
guess and say she is this would not only
be perfect to serve to her but would
also make a beautiful edible gift
although to be honest once you make this
and taste it there is a decent chance
you'll just keep it to yourself and get
her a gift card but either way I really
do hope you give this easy and delicious
chocolate granola try soon so head over
to food wishes calm for all the
ingredient amount somewhere
for as usual and is always enjoy
you
